translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽. The Chapter with Yasas
The Elder Raṭṭhapāla’s Birth Story🔽“I gave a fine elephant
to the Fortunate One Padumuttara,
the Leader of the World, the One of Great Compassion,
with tusks like a ploughshare, and well-grown.
Adorned with a white parasol,🔽with a saddle and a goad,
having had it valued at all,
I had a monastery made.

analyzed: catu paññāsa sahassāni  pāsāde kārayim aha
translated: I had fifty-four thousand🔽houses made,
and having given a great gift,🔽I dedicated it to the Great Seer.
The Great Hero, the Self-Made One, the Foremost Person,
rejoiced,
and making all the people laugh,
he taught the Deathless State.
The Buddha explained it to me,
(saying) it was called the Water-Lotus,
and while sitting in the Community of monks,
he spoke these verses:
‘He had fifty-four thousand
houses made,
I will tell of the outcome,
listen to me as I speak.
There will be eighteen thousand
houses,
and in the highest (heaven) I was reborn,
and they were all made of gold.
Fifty times I was Sakka, King of the Gods,
will rule as king of the gods.
Fifty-eight times
he will be a wheel-turning monarch.
After a hundred thousand aeons,

analyzed: okkāka kula sambhavaḥ  gotamaḥ nāma gottena
translated: born in the Okkāka family,
he will be a teacher in the world🔽known as Gotama by clan.
Having passed away from the world of the gods,

analyzed: sukka mūlena coditaḥ  aḍḍhe kule mahā bhoge
translated: urged on by the root of merit,
he will be reborn in a great and wealthy family.
Later, having gone forth,
urged on by the root of merit,🔽he will be a disciple of the Teacher

analyzed: raṭṭhapālo ti nāmena  hessati satthu sāvakaḥ
translated: known as Raṭṭhapāla.
He will be devoted to striving,
peaceful, free from attachments,
having fully understood all the pollutants,
he will be extinguished without pollutants.’

analyzed: uṭṭhāya abhinikkhamma  jahitāḥ bhoga sampadā  kheḷa piṇḍā iva
translated: Having risen and gone forth,🔽having given up the wealth of possessions,🔽I have no affection for possessions,
which are like a lump of spit.
My energy is the yoke-bearing beast,
the vehicle for attaining safety from bondage.
I bear this last body
in the Dispensation of the Buddha.
My pollutants are destroyed,
I live free from pollutants.
Welcome indeed it was for me
…🔽I have done the Teacher’s bidding.
The four discriminations,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”🔽Thus has it been told.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā raṭṭhapālo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Raṭṭhapālattherassāpadānaṁ ekādasamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā raṭṭhapālaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati  raṭṭhapāla therassa apadānam ekādasama
translated: The Elder Raṭṭhapāla recited these verses.🔽The Story of the Elder Raṭṭhapāla is the eleventh.
The Fifty-sixth Chapter

analyzed: tassa uddāna  yasaḥ nadī kassapaḥ ca
translated: The Summary
Yasa, Nadīkassapa, and Kimbila of Gayā,🔽Vajjiputta,
Two Uttaras, Bhaddaji,
Sivaka, and Upavāna,
Raṭṭhapāla, a hundred and ninety-five,
verses.🔽The Elders’ Birth Stories are finished.
